pullRequest.body:
Co-authored-by: Ruben Van de Velde <ruben.vandevelde+github@gmail.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [c7f8b03c1c](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17483/commits/c7f8b03c1c6684865c9ff85e79a42e5e9e942466)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ add_eq_iff_eq_add`
`+ eq_add_iff_add_eq`
`+ natCast_eq_one_of_odd_of_two_eq_zero`
`+ natCast_eq_zero_of_even_of_two_eq_zero`
`+ natCast_eq_zero_or_one_of_two_eq_zero`
`+ odd_add_one`
`+ of_one_ne_zero_of_two_eq_zero`
`+ two_nsmul`
`+ two_zsmul`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11503491441/job/32020887598)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11503491441/job/32020887802)
I'm not sure about this name, `mk` is usually the constructor of a structure.

This is meant as a pseudo-constructor of sorts. I think the name is fine, since I don't think there's going to be any alternate ways of building the instance that don't just boil down to this, and alternate names like `char_two_of_one_ne_zero_of_two_eq_zero` are way too wordy.
Perhaps also add a `two_smul` version for an arbitrary module, like [two_smul](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Defs.html#two_smul)?
Does that work? `two_smul` takes an argument `x : M` in the monoid, rather than `x : R` in the characteristic two semiring.
I think that is a reasonable request but let's save it for another PR. @Command-Master feel free to PR such a change and ping me.

```suggestion
protected theorem mk (h : (1 : R)  0) (h : (2 : R) = 0) : CharP R 2 where
  cast_eq_zero_iff' n := by
    obtain hn | hn := Nat.even_or_odd n
    췅 simp_rw [hn.two_dvd, iff_true]
      exact natCast_eq_zero_of_even_of_two_eq_zero hn h
    췅 simp_rw [hn.not_two_dvd_nat, iff_false]
      rwa [natCast_eq_one_of_odd_of_two_eq_zero hn h]
```
This syntax is also available: I prefer it, but I do not think that there is a clear style guidance either way.
Sure, I don't mind writing it like this.

```suggestion
theorem sub_eq_add' : (췅 - 췅) = (췅 + 췅 : R  R  R) :=
```
Does this need to exist? Does this need to be `simp`? What is a situation where we want to `simp` to fire with these unapplied?
I wanted to make sure that every single instance of `-` got turned into `+` , though I guess there aren't actually very many instances where `-` is unapplied. Should I just deprecate this lemma?
Yes, it appears unused.
Except in `scripts/no_lints_prime_decls.txt`

```suggestion
theorem of_one_not_zero_two_zero (h : (1 : R)  0) (h : (2 : R) = 0) : CharP R 2 := by
```
`CharTwo.mk` does not trigger this in my brain but I am open to arguments.
Shouldn't it be `of_one_ne_zero_of_two_eq_zero`? I guess this is still less wordy than I was expecting, so I can perform the rename.
Do we need two `of`'s?
Eh, I guess not.
It looks like `of_\w*of_` is sufficiently entrenched.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Algebra/CharP/Two): more lemmas on char two
